important_phrase: Petrochemical, industrial power, transportation, and manufacturing contacts with business dealings in the energy sector described positive outcomes, such as improved profit margins from lower fuel and feedstock costs, as well as steady project bookings through 2015
Motor vehicle dealer contacts indicated lower gas prices helped spur an increase in light truck sales
The decline in fuel prices was overwhelmingly seen as an opportunity to improve margins rather than lower prices
Credit conditions were largely unchanged from the previous reporting period
Supplier delivery times slowed slightly, while contacts reported a moderate rise in finished inventory levels
Since the last report, District brokers' reports on home sales activity improved a bit
Many contacts cited evidence, such as a noticeable increase in purchases of light trucks that lower gasoline prices had led to increased spending on other goods and services
Pricing is not generally noted as an issue, except for some manufacturers' concerns with the strong dollar
Looking forward, contacts generally maintain a steady level of "cautious optimism
Selling prices have generally remained stable, although one firm is escalating renewal prices modestly

The outlook is mostly optimistic across the District, although Hartford and Providence contacts expect slower improvement in commercial real estate fundamentals than do contacts in Boston and Portland
These plans are a reflection of expected continual improvement in general economic conditions, improved consumer sentiment, and hence a better retail environment
Milk prices declined amid rising stocks of dairy products and stalled exports
Credit conditions improved on balance
Wge and non-wage costs changed little on balanced
Credit conditions improved on balance over the reporting period
Growth in business spending slowed to a modest pace in January and early February
Construction and real estate activity increased modestly over the reporting period
Growth was robust for the general merchandise, clothing, and specialty gift sectors, but slower for food, beverages, furniture, and appliances
Overall pricing for materials and equipment was flat
Overall, input and finished goods prices were steady
Auto lending has softened
Finished goods prices held steady
Materials prices were stable apart from increases for drywall and concrete
The share of SUV and truck sales increased by about 7 percentage points compared to last January, which some dealers attributed to significantly lower gasoline prices
The strong dollar has slowed agricultural exports
Demand for oilfield services declined sharply, while agricultural conditions and loan demand improved slightly
Manufacturers generally reported stable selling prices, and flat to lower input costs
Loan demand increased slightly over the past six weeks
Litigation and bankruptcy work picked up, but transaction work for law firm offices in Houston slowed moderately
Commercial real estate activity held steady or slowed since the previous report, and outlooks were cautiously optimistic
Outlooks were positive, and contacts expect modest sales growth over the next three months
Following several years of strong gains, District non-irrigated and irrigated cropland values leveled off while ranchland values continued to rise due to strong demand for good-quality pasture
Prices continued to grow modestly, and wages grew slightly since the previous survey period
Finished goods prices held steady, but were moderately higher than a year ago
Bankers reported mixed loan demand across sectors in January and early February, while loan quality and deposit levels were stable
Overall District manufacturing activity expanded at a slow pace in January and early February, while other business activity increased
Commercial real estate activity continued to rise moderately as vacancy rates decreased and absorption increased at a faster pace
Restaurant sales improved modestly and were considerably above year-ago levels, with positive growth expected in the coming months
However, a clay mine in Montana applied for a permit to expand
The Ninth District economy grew at a moderate pace since the previous report
Nevertheless, wage increases generally remained moderate
A large oil-drilling services company noted recent reduced demand due to lower oil prices
Commercial construction activity increased
Consumer spending increased moderately
Coal production was unchanged in both the Cleveland and Richmond Districts, while it increased modestly in the St Louis District
The demand for nonfinancial services also grew moderately on balance
Most Districts reported flat to slight increases in overall prices
Commercial loan demand increased in New York, was particularly strong in Cleveland and Atlanta, was steady in Kansas City, and was mixed in Richmond
Transportation demand generally improved
Commercial real estate market conditions were stable or improving in most Districts
The Richmond District reported a typical seasonal slowdown in activity
Housing markets were steady to stronger in early 2015
Finally, banking contacts again report lower delinquency rates on consumer loans but little change in delinquencies in other categories

Manufacturing firms report that activity continued to expand at a modest pace in early 2015; while they have grown less optimistic about the near-term outlook, on balance, a growing proportion plan to increase capital spending in the months ahead

New York City's residential rental market has firmed slightly: rents in Manhattan and Brooklyn are reported to be up moderately from a year ago, while they have been steady at an elevated levels in Queens
Retail sales have improved somewhat, on balance, since the last report
Overall, brokers noted some slight improvement in activity
Overall, Third District contacts reported little change to the steady, slight pace of price level increases that was seen in other recent Beige Book periods
Increasing numbers of contacts expressed concerns that competition has lowered lending standards, undercut margins, and is beginning to lower overall credit quality
Nearly as many firms indicated declines in activity as increases
Third District homebuilders provided mixed reports
Contacts remain cautiously optimistic for 2015; however, margins remain tight for retailers, and most shoppers remain focused on low prices
Natural gas prices continued to decline modestly in recent weeks
Retail sales growth slowed
In the service sector, hiring was little changed, although average wages rose more rapidly
Loan demand increased slightly since the previous Beige Book
Inventories of raw materials and finished goods rose moderately, but more slowly than in the previous report
Residential real estate activity increased moderately in recent weeks
Retail price inflation slowed since our last report
Offshore demand for logs, especially from China, slowed, while domestic demand increased slightly
Lending activity increased modestly
Overall price inflation remained modest during the reporting period
Lending activity in the District increased modestly during the reporting period
Overall District manufacturing activity grew moderately
In some relatively fast-growing areas, shortages of skilled labor are contributing to the tepid pace of construction
Overall retail sales activity grew moderately during the reporting period
Missouri exhibited strong production increases in 2014, offsetting decreases observed in other District states
Over the past three months, compared with the same period a year ago, wages have grown moderately while employment and prices charged to consumers have grown modestly

A survey of District businesses indicated that, over the past three months, wages grew moderately while employment and prices charged to consumers grew modestly compared with the same period last year
For standard residential mortgage loans, credit standards were mostly unchanged, creditworthiness of applicants improved, demand was somewhat stronger, and delinquencies were slightly lower
Hiring reports from food manufacturers were mixed
Home sales increased in the Eighth District on a year-over-year basis
Reports from auto dealers were also generally positive
